title: Rescue on Barsoom

campaign_overview.theme: Planetary adventure where bravery, kindness, and clever problem-solving help unite rival groups and protect a princess on a strange world.
campaign_overview.tone_description: Fast-paced and heroic with mystery and big leaps; keep danger non-graphic, focus on rescues, tournaments, and making peace instead of harsh cruelty.
campaign_overview.goal: Help the stranded Earth hero survive on Mars (Barsoom), befriend unlikely allies, rescue Princess Dejah, and stop a forced marriage by ending the war fairly.
campaign_overview.completion_condition: Dejah is safe and free to choose her future, the war between Helium and Zodanga is resolved (peace or decisive victory), and the heroes earn trust from both Red and Green Martians.
player_experience_goals: Feel heroic through daring rescues and athletic stunts
Practice teamwork and negotiation between rival cultures
Solve problems with creative plans instead of only fighting
Make meaningful choices about honor, fairness, and protecting others

starting_state.starting_expectation_for_dm: Begin with a clear opening choice.

acts.title: Stranded Under Two Moons
acts.purpose: Introduce Barsoom’s low-gravity wonders, establish the rivalry between Red and Green Martians, and give the heroes a clear reason to protect Princess Dejah while earning their first allies.
acts.narrative_summary: The Earth hero awakens on Barsoom and discovers that big leaps and daring stunts are suddenly possible. A mysterious conflict pulls the party into danger when they witness a chase involving Red Martian scouts and Green Martian hunters. The heroes must survive the strange landscape, decide who to trust, and prevent an early disaster that would worsen the war. By the end of the act, the party has proof they can be honorable and helpful, earning a fragile alliance and a lead pointing toward Princess Dejah’s whereabouts and the political stakes behind her forced marriage.
key_elements: Low-gravity movement and stunt showcases (leaps, climbs, long jumps)
First contact with Green Martians: proud, practical, suspicious of outsiders
Red Martian politics hinted through scouts, banners, and urgent messages
A public test of honor (trial, contest, or “prove your worth” challenge)
Non-lethal conflict options and rescue-focused stakes
Clue about Dejah’s capture/transport and the marriage plan
possible_player_actions: Attempt a daring rescue during a chase without harming pursuers
Negotiate safe passage by offering help, gifts, or a fair trade
Win trust through a skill challenge: athletics, navigation, empathy, or ingenuity
Use stealth to avoid a fight and gather information from enemy campfires
Protect bystanders/creatures caught in the crossfire to demonstrate heroism
Make a promise or oath that later complicates diplomacy but builds reputation
acts.success_condition: The party secures at least one ally (Green or Red), learns a concrete lead on Dejah’s location/route, and earns a reputation for honor or bravery rather than cruelty.
acts.failure_guidance: If negotiations fail or the party is captured, treat it as a chance to prove character: run a “trial of honor” or tournament to earn release. If they lose the lead, provide an alternate clue (a dropped dispatch, a witness, or a map fragment) that points toward the same destination but adds a time pressure complication.
acts.dm_notes: Keep early danger exciting but non-graphic: falls become big bouncy tumbles; weapons can disarm, entangle, or stun. Reinforce that both Red and Green Martians have good people and bad actors—avoid painting any group as entirely villainous. Offer simple, visible stunt bonuses for creative low-gravity ideas (swinging, vaulting, bounding over hazards). End the act with a clear direction: “Dejah is being moved to X,” plus a reason the party can’t simply walk in (guards, distance, political barriers).

acts.title: Camps, Courts, and the Captive Princess
acts.purpose: Deepen relationships with rival factions, reveal the forced marriage stakes, and place Princess Dejah within reach through a rescue that can be won by cleverness, diplomacy, or honorable competition.
acts.narrative_summary: Travel and intrigue bring the heroes into the heart of Barsoomian conflict: Green Martian camps with strict customs and Red Martian halls filled with worried leaders and daring champions. The party learns that Dejah’s forced marriage is being used as a political weapon to end the war unfairly. The heroes must navigate etiquette, earn trust in tense rooms, and choose how to approach Dejah’s captivity—sneak her out, win her freedom through a contest, or broker a temporary truce that forces the captors to negotiate. The act ends with Dejah freed or in the heroes’ protection, but the enemy’s larger plan is now in motion, pushing everyone toward a final confrontation.
key_elements: Faction diplomacy scenes with clear “what each side wants”
Kid-friendly intrigue: overheard plans, coded messages, misunderstandings
A tournament/arena/test of champions as an alternate to combat
Rescue set-piece: prison wagon, guarded tower, or ceremonial pavilion
Dejah as an active ally with agency and expertise, not a passive prize
Moral choice: quick escape vs. stopping collateral harm vs. keeping promises
possible_player_actions: Learn and follow customs to avoid offense and gain an audience
Expose a false rumor or planted evidence to prevent a needless battle
Plan a rescue using distractions, decoys, and non-lethal tools
Enter a tournament to win concessions or legal custody of the princess
Convince a Green leader and Red leader to cooperate for a limited mission
Ask Dejah what she wants and build the plan around her choices
acts.success_condition: Princess Dejah is safely freed or placed under the party’s protection, and the heroes secure a path toward ending the war (a negotiation channel, a strategic advantage, or proof that undermines the forced marriage plot).
acts.failure_guidance: If the rescue attempt fails, Dejah can still send aid: a hidden message, a sympathetic guard, or a public statement that buys time. If the party angers a faction, introduce a mediator NPC who offers a “make it right” mission (escort civilians, recover stolen supplies, or stop a rogue warband) to restore trust without erasing consequences.
acts.dm_notes: Give Dejah clear strengths (leadership, knowledge of geography/politics, compassion) and let her contribute meaningfully during scenes. Make contests feel fair: multiple ways to win (athletics, tactics, teamwork, clever gadgets). Keep villains’ threats focused on control and intimidation, not cruelty. Track a simple “Trust” meter for Red Martians and Green Martians; player choices should move it up/down and matter in Act 3.

acts.title: Two Cities, One Future
acts.purpose: Deliver a heroic finale where the party chooses how to resolve the war (peace or decisive victory), stops the forced marriage, and unites rivals through bravery, kindness, and clever problem-solving.
acts.narrative_summary: With Dejah safe and the enemy plot exposed, Barsoom races toward a breaking point: an arranged wedding, a looming battle, or both. The heroes must act fast to prevent a political trap from becoming a bloodless-but-unjust takeover or a full-scale war. Their allies call in favors earned earlier—guides, mounts, secret tunnels, honored champions—to reach the decisive moment. In the finale, the party confronts the masterminds behind the forced marriage, defuses a battle through diplomacy and proof, or wins a decisive victory while protecting noncombatants. The story ends with Dejah free to choose her future and the heroes recognized as bridge-builders between Red and Green Martians.
key_elements: Final set-piece at a wedding ceremony, battlefield ridge, or city gate
A “stop the plan” objective with multiple solutions (debate, proof, duel, sabotage)
Non-lethal combat options and clear civilian-protection goals
A big low-gravity stunt moment that feels earned and cinematic
Reappearance of earlier NPCs whose trust depends on prior choices
A formal resolution: treaty, truce, or honorable surrender
possible_player_actions: Present evidence publicly to force negotiations or cancel the ceremony
Challenge the antagonist to an honorable duel or champion’s trial
Coordinate a rescue-and-evacuation for civilians to prevent panic
Use stealth to disable a war trigger (signal device, sabotage order, false banner)
Broker a peace by offering fair terms and addressing both sides’ fears
Choose mercy for defeated foes to build long-term stability
acts.success_condition: Dejah is safe and free to choose her future, the forced marriage is prevented, and the Helium–Zodanga conflict is resolved by peace or decisive victory while the heroes earn trust from both Red and Green Martians.
acts.failure_guidance: If the party cannot stop the ceremony or battle in time, shift to damage control: protect innocents, capture the true instigators, and create a chance for an immediate ceasefire after a brief, non-lethal clash. If peace talks collapse, allow a “decisive victory” route that still highlights fairness (accept surrender, protect prisoners, prevent revenge). End with a hopeful path forward even if the outcome is imperfect.
acts.dm_notes: Make the climax about choices, not just fighting: offer at least three viable approaches (diplomacy, contest/duel, stealth/sabotage) and let earlier trust levels unlock advantages. Keep stakes clear and kid-appropriate: focus on preventing harm, stopping unfair control, and protecting community. Reward teamwork with tangible narrative payoffs (allies arrive, doors open, crowds listen). Close with epilogues for each faction and a personal moment where Dejah asserts her agency and thanks the heroes for respecting her decisions.

locations.name: Crash Ridge on the Thark Plains
locations.description: A wind-carved ridge overlooking the ochre plains where the Earth hero first awakens under two moons. Strange, light gravity turns every scramble into a soaring leap, but the open ground makes it easy to be spotted by patrols and hunting parties.
notable_features: Low-gravity cliffs and bouncy falls that enable dramatic stunts
Fossil-like rock arches that create natural obstacle courses
Distant banners and dust trails hinting at Red and Green patrol routes
A half-buried supply satchel/dispatch case that can provide the first lead
Skittish local creatures that can be calmed, guided, or accidentally stampeded

locations.name: Thark Encampment & the Circle of Honor
locations.description: A sprawling Green Martian camp of hide tents, towering watch-poles, and tethered thoats. Outsiders are treated with suspicion, but the Tharks respect bravery and fairness—especially when proven in their formal Circle of Honor.
notable_features: The Circle of Honor: a public, rules-bound challenge where violence can be non-lethal
Customs board: simple pictograms of taboos and respected gestures (great for kid-friendly roleplay)
Chieftain’s platform where negotiations and oaths are witnessed by the tribe
Weapon racks with nets, bolas, and stun-sticks emphasizing capture over harm
Gossip fires where overheard talk can reveal Dejah’s transport route

locations.name: Helium’s Skyhall Courts
locations.description: A bright, airy complex of red stone terraces and canal-bridges where Red Martian leaders argue strategy, champions train, and messengers arrive breathless with news. The heroes can earn official support—but only if they navigate etiquette and politics.
notable_features: Audience chamber with strict speaking order and opportunities for persuasive proof
Training terrace for friendly sparring, teamwork drills, or a champion’s demonstration
Message gallery of coded banners and wax-sealed dispatches (a clue puzzle)
Balcony routes and ropeways perfect for stealthy approaches or daring rescues
Trust ledger: a visible way to track reputation with Red Martians

locations.name: Zodangan Prison Wagon & Ceremonial Pavilion
locations.description: A guarded, moving pavilion-wagon used to transport honored captives in public view—meant to look “proper” while still controlling them. It’s surrounded by soldiers, but also by rules, schedules, and pride that clever heroes can exploit.
notable_features: Procession timetable that allows planned distractions and timed escapes
Silk-screen walls that conceal silhouettes—useful for misdirection
Non-lethal security: mancatchers, tether-lines, and locking canopy poles
A sympathetic attendant who can pass messages or small tools to Dejah
A legal loophole placard describing challenge-rights (duel/contest option)

locations.name: Two Moons Gate & the Wedding Dais
locations.description: A grand gate plaza between towering walls where a political wedding and a military mobilization can collide. Crowds, banners, and signal-horns make this a place where a single brave act—or a single revealed truth—can change the fate of two cities.
notable_features: Wedding dais with public microphones/echo-horns for declarations and evidence
Signal platform that can trigger troop movements unless disabled or redirected
Rooftop chain-bridges enabling a climactic low-gravity leap sequence
Protected civilian zones that create clear rescue-and-evacuation objectives
Champion’s circle for an honorable duel that can replace a larger battle

npcs.name: Tars Tarkas
npcs.role: Green Martian chieftain and potential early ally; judge in the Circle of Honor
npcs.personality: Stern but fair; values courage, honesty, and restraint. Suspicious of outsiders at first, yet quietly compassionate toward the vulnerable.
npcs.motivation: Protect his people’s survival and honor while preventing reckless choices that would ignite a larger war; test whether the heroes are trustworthy enough to be allies.
possible_dialogue_hooks: “On these plains, strength without honor is just noise. Show me what you are.”
“You may speak—but in the Circle, your deeds must match your words.”
“Red and Green both bleed the same dust. The question is who profits from the fighting.”
“Win respect here, and you earn more than freedom—you earn a name.”

npcs.name: Princess Dejah Thoris
npcs.role: Red Martian princess, scientist-diplomat, and active co-planner of the rescue and peace effort
npcs.personality: Brave, warm, and sharp-minded; proud without being cruel. Refuses to be treated as a prize and expects allies to respect consent and choice.
npcs.motivation: Stay free to choose her own future, protect Helium’s people, and end the war in a way that doesn’t humiliate the defeated or endanger civilians.
possible_dialogue_hooks: “If you came to ‘save’ me, start by asking what I want.”
“A forced marriage is not peace—it’s a cage painted gold.”
“There’s a way through this that spares lives. Help me make them listen.”
“I can get us inside… but only if we do this with honor.”

npcs.name: Sola of the Procession
npcs.role: Young attendant/guard assigned to the Zodangan prison pavilion; secret helper and message-runner
npcs.personality: Nervous but kind; observant, quick to empathize, and braver than she thinks when someone is being treated unfairly.
npcs.motivation: Prevent a public injustice and protect innocents caught in politics; prove to herself she can choose what is right over what is ordered.
possible_dialogue_hooks: “I’m not supposed to talk to you… but this isn’t right.”
“The schedule—there’s a gap when the horns change. That’s your moment.”
“If you promise no one gets hurt, I can slip her a tool.”
“They keep saying it’s ‘for peace.’ Peace shouldn’t need chains.”

npcs.name: Sab Than
npcs.role: Zodangan war-leader and public face of the forced marriage plan; final-act antagonist for debate, duel, or exposure
npcs.personality: Charismatic and domineering; uses “order” and “peace” language to justify control. Hates losing face more than losing a fight.
npcs.motivation: Secure power by ending the war on his terms through a political marriage, public spectacle, and a narrative that paints resistance as chaos.
possible_dialogue_hooks: “Witness the ‘peace’ I bring—sign it, or be blamed for the storm that follows.”
“A champion’s duel? Fine. Let the crowd learn who deserves to lead.”
“You want fairness? Then present your proof before everyone—if you dare.”
“Mercy is weakness… unless it belongs to me.”

dm_guidance.completion_behavior: Celebrate the ending and state the adventure is complete.

intro: Red sand crunches under your boots as you wake in a sun-baked riverbed beneath a copper sky. The air is thin, your heart pounds—and when you stand, your body feels strangely light, as if the world itself is urging you to leap farther, run faster, and dare bigger. Broken canal ruins twist across the plain like giant ribs, and a warm red gemstone pendant rests in your hand, humming with a secret you don’t yet understand. On the horizon, towering figures ride toward you—Green Martian scouts of the Thark horde—watching to see if you are prey, a curiosity… or a hero. Somewhere beyond the jagged hills, two great cities wage war, and Princess Dejah’s fate hangs on a choice only the brave can change.

ruleset.system_name: Kid-friendly pulp sci-fi rules with low-gravity stunt bonuses, simple social checks for diplomacy, and non-lethal combat options
